qas.question: Which model explains why bob has an easier time reading a book, and then discussing it rather than reading two books?
Which concept is criticised for being unworthy and too broad?
Which part of memory allows us to go about our daily lives?
What does the non-working memory model explain?
What has been praised as adequate and non-vague?

plausible_answers.text: what allows us to do everyday activities involving thought

qas.question: What is non-working memory also the premise for?
Which part of memory allows us to go about our long-term lives?
Which model explains why bob has an easier time writing a book, and then discussing it rather than writing two books?

context: The <a0_0><b7_0>working memory model<b7_0/><a0_0/> explains <b3_0>many practical observations<b3_0/>, such as why it is easier to do two different tasks (one verbal and one visual) than two similar tasks (e.g., two visual), and the aforementioned word-length effect. However, the <a1_0>concept of a <b4_0>central executive<b4_0/><a1_0/> as noted here has been criticised as inadequate and vague.[citation needed] <a2_0><b6_0>Working memory<b6_0/><a2_0/> is also the premise for <b5_0>what allows us to do everyday activities involving thought<b5_0/>. It is the section of memory where we carry out thought processes and use them to learn and reason about topics.
